discussion.content: wouldn't a NSG outbound rule associated with subnet1-1 be sufficient?

comments.content: Agreed, I think additional information is missing from this question. so either an NSG on subnet 1, or if you need to use an existing firewall (policy), we need to create a network rule (opposed to an application rule)

discussion.content:
NSG for the win!
If you need centralized and advanced traffic control or require FQDN-based filtering, Azure Firewall is the better choice. However, if your requirements are simple, NSGs can be sufficient.

NSG on subnet1-1 that denies outbound on port 80 and 443 should be enough in my view.
For other subnets, outbound to http/https in allowed even with NSG default rules.

comments.content: yes, I did this recently in my actual work
A Private endpoint would not restrict access, per se.

To ensure that subnet3-2 can only access resources on subnet3-1 in Azure, you can use Network Security Groups (NSGs) and Service Endpoints. Hereâ€™s a step-by-step guide:

Create Network Security Groups (NSGs):
Create an NSG for subnet3-2 and another for subnet3-1.
In the NSG for subnet3-2, add an inbound security rule that allows traffic to subnet3-1.
Configure NSG Rules:
For the NSG associated with subnet3-2, add a rule to allow traffic to subnet3-1:
Source: subnet3-2
Destination: subnet3-1
Port: Any (or specify the required port)

Apply NSGs to Subnets:
Apply the NSG with the inbound rule to subnet3-2.
Ensure subnet3-1 has an NSG that allows traffic from subnet3-2 if needed.

You are planning security for Azure Front Door.

You need to create a rule that can be applied to Front Door hosts. The rule must prevent hosts in Japan from making more than 50 requests per minute. You do NOT need to associate the rule to a Front Door instance to complete this task.

To complete this task, sign in to the Azure portal.

discussion.content:
Tested in portal:
Create WAF policy standard or premium (Global WAF (Froont Door)), Policy mode prevention, add custom rule with type as rate limit, priority 1, rate limit duration 1min, rate limit threshold 50, in condition match type select Geo location, Match variable SocketAddr or RemoteAddr imo it is not important (SocketAddr means that if client use proxy or LB it will use IP of the proxy or LB, with RemoteAddr, it will be original IP of the client), Operation -> Country: Japan, Then Deny traffic. 
More information:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-pages/security/web-application-firewall-custom-rule-sets
you should also add a "GeoMatch" condition for Geo-Filtering in a Custom Rule of WAF policy

If the question says "planning security for Azure Front Door", shouldn't you us 'Front Door' (Global) over 'Application Gateway' (Regional)? The Instructions say Application Gateway, but the screen shot looks like Front door.

comments.content: correct. We should use Global WAF(front door) policy
